image.altText: A composite image of muddy flooded machinery, a large sinkhole, and a metal pipe with gas coming out of it.

items.synopsis: Snowy Hydro's tunnelling machine caused a sinkhole and spent months barely moving, then the troubled project's tunnel began filling with gas.

title.children: 'You've screwed up, haven't you?': The $2 billion mistake behind Snowy 2.0

image.altText: A man carries a young girl wearing pink pyjamas with a worried and urgent expression on his face

items.synopsis: If we do not understand the pain and misery on both sides of this war, then we cannot begin to think of how to help stop the never-ending cycle of pain and misery in Gaza, writes John Lyons.

title.children: Gaza is the most miserable place on Earth and in Israel, fear is everywhere. This tragedy cannot go on

image.altText: People wearing various uniforms, one saying UN, standing in front of a truck with boxes on board

items.synopsis: The UN says the second convoy of aid trucks which have gone into Gaza only accounts for "about 3 per cent of the daily average volume" of supplies the area received before fresh hostilities. Follow live.

title.children: UN says latest aid trucks 'about 3 per cent' of Gaza's pre-war daily supplies

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin say the United States expects the Israel-Gaza war to escalate through involvement by proxies of Iran. They asserted that the Biden administration is prepared to respond if American personnel or armed forces become the target of any such hostilities. "This is not what we want, not what we're looking for. We don't want escalation," Mr Blinken said. "We don't want to see our forces or our personnel come under fire. But if that happens, we're ready for it." Mr Austin, echoed the sentiment saying "what we're seeing is a prospect of a significant escalation of attacks on our troops and our people throughout the region." He said the US has the right to self-defense "and we won't hesitate to take the appropriate action." Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian discussed the means of stopping the Israeli "brutal crimes" in the besieged Gaza enclave, the group said in a statement late Sunday. AP/Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: High-ranking US officials: US prepared to respond if it becomes a target

children.content: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin say the United States expects the Israel-Gaza war to escalate through involvement by proxies of Iran.
They asserted that the Biden administration is prepared to respond if American personnel or armed forces become the target of any such hostilities.
"This is not what we want, not what we're looking for. We don't want escalation," Mr Blinken said.
"We don't want to see our forces or our personnel come under fire. But if that happens, we're ready for it."
Mr Austin, echoed the sentiment saying "what we're seeing is a prospect of a significant escalation of attacks on our troops and our people throughout the region."
He said the US has the right to self-defense "and we won't hesitate to take the appropriate action."

Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian discussed the means of stopping the Israeli "brutal crimes" in the besieged Gaza enclave, the group said in a statement late Sunday.
AP/Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Gaza's most crowded United Nations relief shelter is currently sheltering around 21,000 people, according to the UN's latest update. "The number of [displaced people] per shelter has reached in many shelters 4,400," the update says, adding the buildings were "designed to host 1,500-2,000". It also notes "entire neighbourhoods" have been destroyed in the Gaza Strip since October 7. "The Gaza Ministry of Public Works reported the destruction of 15,749 housing units and the rendering of 10,935 housing units uninhabitable, as of 21 October," it says. "Another 142,500 housing units sustained minor to moderate damage. " The total number of housing units destroyed or damaged accounts for at least 43 per cent of all housing units in the Gaza Strip."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 43 per cent of Gaza's homes destroyed as thousands search for shelter

children.content: Gaza's most crowded United Nations relief shelter is currently sheltering around 21,000 people, according to the UN's latest update.
"The number of [displaced people] per shelter has reached in many shelters 4,400," the update says, adding the buildings were "designed to host 1,500-2,000".

props.alt: A graph showing the number of destroyed buildings split into lightly damaged, severely damaged and uninhabitable, and destroyed

children.content: (United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs)
It also notes "entire neighbourhoods" have been destroyed in the Gaza Strip since October 7.
"The Gaza Ministry of Public Works reported the destruction of 15,749 housing units and the rendering of 10,935 housing units uninhabitable, as of 21 October," it says.
"Another 142,500 housing units sustained minor to moderate damage.
" The total number of housing units destroyed or damaged accounts for at least 43 per cent of all housing units in the Gaza Strip."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The 14 trucks that entered Gaza today account for "about 3 per cent of the daily average volume " of supplies the area received before fresh hostilities flared, according to the United Nations. The aid marks "another glimmer of hope", the organisation said in its latest update, but called for fuel supplies to be allowed in "immediately". "Aid deliveries entering Gaza have not included fuel," the report said. "UNRWA, by far the largest humanitarian provider in Gaza, will exhaust its fuel reserves within the next three days."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UN says latest trucks 'about 3 per cent' of Gaza's pre-war daily supplies

children.content: The 14 trucks that entered Gaza today account for "about
3 per cent of the daily average volume
" of supplies the area received before fresh hostilities flared, according to the United Nations.
The aid marks "another glimmer of hope",
the organisation said in its latest update, but called for fuel supplies to be allowed in "immediately".
"Aid deliveries entering Gaza have not included fuel," the report said.
"UNRWA, by far the largest humanitarian provider in Gaza, will exhaust its fuel reserves within the next three days."

image.altText: A man and woman stand in doorway with their young daughter and baby is held in the arms of her mother

image.altText: two people are seen up against a rail overlooking the water at a sydney beach on a hot day

title.children: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce is a phenomenon that is not going away — here's what it means for the NFL

title.children: Albanese is finally getting his US visit, but America's wild dysfunction complicates the trip

title.children: Plans for $3m fossil museum scrapped after scientist cops online abuse

title.children: There are billions of reasons to fix tax evasion. Experts say saving democracy is one of them

image.altText: Kitchen worker uses tongs in a pub kitchen in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank is deadly serious about maintaining the welfare of all Australians, but it's also deadly serious about anchoring inflation and it won't stop until that's achieved, writes David Taylor.

title.children: We'll soon have the next piece of the puzzle on inflation — and it'll impact whether interest rates go up

image.altText: Two children.

items.synopsis: The aunt and uncle of two children who died and two others who were severely injured in a shed fire in Geelong say their mother tried to save them as she pulled them from the flames.

title.children: Geelong family reeling after shed fire kills two young children and injures siblings

image.altText: India and New Zealand players stand in the fog

items.synopsis: Heavy fog stopped play for a brief period in Dharamsala, but it could only delay India's march to victory against New Zealand, with Virat Kohli scoring 95.

title.children: India beat New Zealand — and the Himalayan fog — to remain perfect at the Cricket World Cup

image.altText: woman behind the steering wheel in a car

items.synopsis: Moreton Bay has 94 suburbs, takes nearly an hour to traverse and is expecting 240 new residents a week for the next 25 years. But those who live here fear they're not prepared to cope with the impending population explosion.

title.children: This council is expecting 240 new residents a week for the next 25 years — and that has some concerned

image.altText: An aerial view of a house and outbuildings on a green patch, surrounded by burnt bushland.

items.synopsis: As the climate changes, an increasing number of houses in Australia are projected to be exposed to bushfires. Now, a new tool, flagged by a royal commission, has been developed that lets individuals and communities realise their vulnerabilities, plan for change and go into the next disaster better prepared.

title.children: 'I wish I'd made my house resilient for far less money': How to build a house that can survive extreme weather

image.altText: A downcast man pops tablets into his hand

items.synopsis: Psoriasis affects an estimated 2 to 4 per cent of Australians, and its physical, mental and financial toll can be devastating.

title.children: Don's skin disease is common but trying to manage it consumed his life for 15 years

image.altText: A footballer attempts to guide the ball into the net as a goalkeeper lunges to stop it.

image.altText: A black and white photo of a woman.

items.synopsis: Detectives say a mystery photo found in the case file of an unknown woman found dead in 1966 at Sorrento could be the missing piece of the puzzle.

title.children: Photo clue in 57-year-old Victorian cold case mystery

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Israel-Gaza war helped send US 10-year bond rates within a whisker of 5 per cent on Friday, leaving Wall Street in the red every session last week, with the ASX again following. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX continues slide as Israel-Gaza war worries see bond interest rates push higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to a new report from the EU Tax Observatory, which has found profit shifting by multinational firms deprived Australia's Treasury of almost $11 billion in 2020. It's part of a system that is depriving governments all over the world of much needed funds — and the report suggests Australians hold more than $370 billion in known tax havens, where they pay only minimal tax. Although changes to bank secrecy laws are having an impact on tax avoidance, there is more Australia could to do, and the report itself is calling for a global minimum tax rate for billionaires. You can hear more about this landmark report and what recommendations it's made from business reporter Daniel Ziffer below : If you don't have time to watch the key takeaways, don't stress — you can also give it a read below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 📺 Australians are holding more than $370 billion in foreign tax havens

That's the lowest since November 4 last year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With Rabobank's global strategist Michael Every joining The Business for a chat later today, let's have a look at some highlights from his daily note with offsider Benjamin Picton. They continue to warn that geopolitical events risk overtaking, and overwhelming, financial ones. "Even the Federal Reserve now warns of growing geopolitical risks to the global financial system," they note. "And if they are finally prepared to talk about it, markets should be concerned. "This is going to be a very tense week. And, sadly, it's hard to see a realistic off-ramp. "The confluence of risks in the Middle East threatens a geopolitical chain reaction that has the potential to make monetary reactions look like small beer by comparison." Not that there aren't some potentially worrying financial developments either. Japanese inflation finally looks to be escaping the doldrums, prompting noises that the Bank of Japan will gradually edge further away from its aggressive policies to keep interest rates ultra low. "Evaporating monetary easing from the Bank of Japan comes at a delicate moment," they observe. "The USA is running colossal deficits to finance their guns and butter spending, China is selling Treasuries to defend the CNY, and Argentina *could* be poised to elect a Libertarian President who has promised to dollarise the economy. " The threat of a global liquidity squeeze raises questions for markets where fragilities have already been exposed by the UK pension blowup and the mini banking crisis in the USA and Switzerland. "A scramble for cash is underway, which probably means that somebody is going to miss out. "What does that mean for emerging markets that the USA needs to keep in the geopolitical tent? "If the BOJ retracts the control rod of yield curve control from the monetary reactor core, will this set off a chain reaction in bond markets that will break something else?" You can listen to more of what Michael Every has to say when he speaks with Kirsten Aiken by tuning into The Business on ABC News channel at 8:45pm AEDT or watching back on iView.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Growing geopolitical risks to the global financial system'

children.content: With
Rabobank's global strategist Michael Every
joining The Business for a chat later today, let's have a look at some highlights from his daily note with offsider
Benjamin Picton
They continue to warn that geopolitical events risk overtaking, and overwhelming, financial ones.
"Even the Federal Reserve now warns of growing geopolitical risks to the global financial system," they note.
"And if they are finally prepared to talk about it, markets should be concerned.
"This is going to be a very tense week. And, sadly, it's hard to see a realistic off-ramp.
"The confluence of risks in the Middle East threatens
a geopolitical chain reaction that has the potential to make monetary reactions look like small beer
by comparison."
Not that there aren't some potentially worrying financial developments either.
Japanese inflation finally looks to be escaping the doldrums, prompting noises that the
Bank of Japan
will gradually edge further away from its aggressive policies to keep interest rates ultra low.
"Evaporating monetary easing from the Bank of Japan comes at a delicate moment," they observe.

"The USA is running colossal deficits to finance their guns and butter spending, China is selling Treasuries to defend the CNY, and Argentina *could* be poised to elect a Libertarian President who has promised to dollarise the economy.
The threat of a global liquidity squeeze
raises questions for markets where fragilities have already been exposed by the UK pension blowup and the mini banking crisis in the USA and Switzerland.
"A scramble for cash is underway, which probably means that somebody is going to miss out.
"What does that mean for emerging markets that the USA needs to keep in the geopolitical tent?
"If the BOJ retracts the control rod of yield curve control from the monetary reactor core, will this set off a chain reaction in
bond markets
that will break something else?"
You can listen to more of what
Michael Every
has to say when he speaks with

by tuning into

channel

or watching back on iView.

items.synopsis: Indigenous leaders who supported the Yes case at last week’s Voice referendum have written to the prime minister saying the No vote was a “shameful victory”.

title.children: Indigenous leaders break their silence, call referendum defeat 'appalling and mean-spirited'

image.altText: a bunch of macadamia nuts, still in their shells, hang off a twiggy branch with living green leaves

items.synopsis: A plan of action is adopted to help save the world's only wild macadamia plants from extinction.

title.children: Macadamias 'as rare as the Wollemi pine' get new national recovery plan

image.altText: An ibis chick at Humpybong Park

items.synopsis: In Moreton Bay, thousands of the infamous 'bin chicken' have taken up residence across 40 colonies — and some of them have been found to travel up to 750 kilometres.

title.children: Three ibis travelled hundreds of kilometres across Queensland. What does their journey tell us?
